paragraphs.text:
%md
# Loading the GS data into HDFS

Since data can only be queried if they are stored inside HDFS, therefore we will first transfer the data from GS to HDFS for HiveQL querying.

- Block 1: create an external table to store the GS data in HDFS user home directory
- Block 2: import into the newly created table `wdi_csv_text` the GS data in `wdi_gs`
- Block 3 - 4: running the query to count the number of rows twice and compare their performance

msg.data:
Loading the GS data into HDFS

Since data can only be queried if they are stored inside HDFS, therefore we will first transfer the data from GS to HDFS for HiveQL querying.

  • Block 1: create an external table to store the GS data in HDFS user home directory
  • Block 2: import into the newly created table wdi_csv_text the GS data in wdi_gs
  • Block 3 - 4: running the query to count the number of rows twice and compare their performance

paragraphs.text:
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE IF NOT EXISTS wdi_csv_text
(year INTEGER, countryName STRING, countryCode STRING, indicatorName STRING, indicatorCode STRING, indicatorValue FLOAT)
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED FIELDS TERMINATED BY ',' LINES TERMINATED BY '\n'
LOCATION 'hdfs:///user/ziyang/hive/wdi/wdi_csv_text'

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Performance Analysis
First we inspect the file sizes of the data file stored in HDFS using below commands, we found that the whole dataset is stored in HDFS as 5 separated chunks, and that their total size is 1.7GB (comparing to the original 2.21GB file size.)
- `hdfs dfs -ls -h /user/ziyang/hive/wdi/wdi_csv_text` to display size of each sub-part of the file
- `hdfs dfs -du -s -h /user/ziyang/hive/wdi/wdi_csv_text` to display the total size of the file.

Then, we run the below queries to count the total number of rows in the dataset. We see that it took 24 seconds for the first time but only 16 seconds for the second time, and this is because that after running the first query, HDFS cache holds the data read in that query temporarily, therefore any subsequent queries that retrieve the same section of data will only need to read from the cache rather than the disk, which accelerate repeated retrivals. Now, if we run the following commands on both master and worker nodes to clean the filesystem cache and run the same query again, it will take 24 seconds to read again.
- `echo 3 | sudo tee /proc/sys/vm/drop_caches`

Then, we run the below queries to count the total number of rows in the dataset. We see that it took 24 seconds for the first time but only 16 seconds for the second time, and this is because that after running the first query, HDFS cache holds the data read in that query temporarily, therefore any subsequent queries that retrieve the same section of data will only need to read from the cache rather than the disk, which accelerate repeated retrivals. Now, if we run the following commands on both master and worker nodes to clean the filesystem cache and run the same query again, it will take 24 seconds to read again.
- echo 3 | sudo tee /proc/sys/vm/drop_caches

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Hive vs. Bash

In this section, we will compare the performance of counting the number of rows in the table using HiveQL and bash scripts.

- Block 1: bash scripts to copy `wdi_csv_text` from HDFS to the local directory in the master node, and count the number of rows
- Block 2: performance analysis of Hive and Bash row count

msg.data:
Hive vs. Bash

In this section, we will compare the performance of counting the number of rows in the table using HiveQL and bash scripts.

  • Block 1: bash scripts to copy wdi_csv_text from HDFS to the local directory in the master node, and count the number of rows
  • Block 2: performance analysis of Hive and Bash row count

paragraphs.text:
%sh
# copying the data file from HDFS to local directory in the master node
cd ~
hdfs dfs -get hdfs:///user/ziyang/hive/wdi/wdi_csv_text .

# clear cache and then count the number of rows
echo 3 | sudo tee /proc/sys/vm/drop_caches
cd wdi_csv_text
date +%s && cat * | wc && date +%s

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Performance Analysis

First, we verified the output from the bash scripts (21759408) matches our HiveQL query result. Notice that the bash scripts took 28 seconds to finish, which is 4 seconds slower than HiveQL, which seems not that significant. However, taking into account that a HiveQL job will go through the job coordination by YARN comparing to the rather simple process with bash command, we are certain that as the table size gets larger, the speed advantage of HiveQL will become increasingly significant.

%md
# Parsing Issues

## Identify the parsing issues using a query

After running the below queries, we see that the results are showing some inconsistencies as the query seems to be reading the wrong columns, and this could result from the default SerDe setting of the table when reading from the original data file. Now, we will create a temporary external debug table that only contains 1 column without any SerDe parsing.

msg.data:
Parsing Issues

Identify the parsing issues using a query

After running the below queries, we see that the results are showing some inconsistencies as the query seems to be reading the wrong columns, and this could result from the default SerDe setting of the table when reading from the original data file. Now, we will create a temporary external debug table that only contains 1 column without any SerDe parsing.

paragraphs.text:
SELECT distinct(indicatorcode)
FROM wdi_csv_text
ORDER BY indicatorcode
LIMIT 20

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Create an external debug table to examine the parsing issue

Now we create an external debug table `wdi_gs_debug` with only 1 column without any SerDe parsing, and query the lines that have parsing issue. By examining the lines that have parsing issues, we see that contents of those rows before the `indicatorcode` field contains the character `,`, which will make the default SerDe to separate those into different columns, therefore in the final results, `indicatorcode` column may not corresponds to the values that it should hold. We can solve the parsing issue by using an OpenCSV SerDe instead of the Hive default one.

## Create a new table with OpenCSV SerDe

- Block 1: create a new table `wdi_opencsv_gs` at Google Storage using the OpenCSV SerDe
- Block 2: create a table `wdi_opencsv_text` at HDFS to hold the data
- Block 3: transfer the data from the GS table to the HDFS one
- Block 4 & 5: verify the result of the originally messed-up query and compare execution time

msg.data:
Create a new table with OpenCSV SerDe

  • Block 1: create a new table wdi_opencsv_gs at Google Storage using the OpenCSV SerDe
  • Block 2: create a table wdi_opencsv_text at HDFS to hold the data
  • Block 3: transfer the data from the GS table to the HDFS one

(year INTEGER, countryName STRING, countryCode STRING, indicatorName STRING, indicatorCode STRING, indicatorValue FLOAT)

LOCATION 'gs://jarvis_data_eng_ziyang/datasets/wdi_2016'
TBLPROPERTIES ("skip.header.line.count"="1")

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Performance Analysis

We see that now the query produces the desired outputs. Notice that both loading data from the GS table into the HDFS table and executing the original query became slower with OpenCSVSerde comparing to the default SerDe. This is because a more complicated SerDe takes more time in the MapReduce `InputFormat -> InputSplit -> RecordReader` pipeline step, and that Hive is schema-on-read, so row formats are checked in query time, therefore a more complex SerDe structure also takes more time.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# OpenCSV SerDe Limitations

Even though OpenCSV SerDe can provide good formatting when loading data into a Hive table, one of the biggest pitfalls it has is that it treats all column fields as type `STRING`, which may not be convenient for numeric-focused queries. However, we can create a view on top of the OpenCSV SerDe table to convert those column fields to types we want.

- Block 1: describe the schema of the OpenCSV Serde table
- Block 2 - 3: create a view on top of the OpenCSV Serde table to transform column types for more convinient querying, and display its format

%md
# 2015 Canada GDP Growth HiveQL

We want to find the growth rate of Canadian GDP in 2015 using HiveQL and discuss the performance of the query.

- Block 1: a HiveQL query to find the 2015 Canada GDP growth based on column fields `indicatorname` and `indicatorvalue`
- Block 2: performance analysis of the HiveQL query

msg.data:
2015 Canada GDP Growth HiveQL

We want to find the growth rate of Canadian GDP in 2015 using HiveQL and discuss the performance of the query.

  • Block 1: a HiveQL query to find the 2015 Canada GDP growth based on column fields indicatorname and indicatorvalue
  • Block 2: performance analysis of the HiveQL query

paragraphs.text:
SELECT countryName, year, indicatorValue AS gdp_growth_rate
FROM wdi_opencsv_text_view
WHERE countryName='Canada' AND year=2015 AND indicatorName LIKE "%GDP growth \(annual \%\)%"

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Performance Analysis

Note that Hive actually took 45 seconds to run a simple query like this, especially comparing to the 24 seconds for counting the total number of rows. This is because to locate the desired row, the execution engine will actually scan through all rows in the table to find a match for the `WHERE` clause. To optimize the performance of this query, we can perform partitioning with the table by country or year.

%md
# Hive Partitions

As mentioned above, we want to partition the table by year to speed up the query, and we will do this with Hive dynamic partitioning. Note that in Hive, partitioned tables will be stored in HDFS as a tree-like subdirectory structures, and therefore we can get the number of partitions easily using the `hdfs -ls` command.

- Block 1: create a new table `wdi_opencsv_text_partitions` which is partitioned by `year`
- Block 2 & 3: setting the mode to be dynamic partition, and load data from `wdi_opencsv_text` to the new partitioned table
- Block 4: inspect the number of partitions created with the new table
- Block 5 & 6: re-run the 2015 Canada GDP growth query against the partitioned table and discuss performance

msg.data:
Hive Partitions

As mentioned above, we want to partition the table by year to speed up the query, and we will do this with Hive dynamic partitioning. Note that in Hive, partitioned tables will be stored in HDFS as a tree-like subdirectory structures, and therefore we can get the number of partitions easily using the hdfs -ls command.

  • Block 1: create a new table wdi_opencsv_text_partitions which is partitioned by year
  • Block 2 & 3: setting the mode to be dynamic partition, and load data from wdi_opencsv_text to the new partitioned table
  • Block 4: inspect the number of partitions created with the new table
  • Block 5 & 6: re-run the 2015 Canada GDP growth query against the partitioned table and discuss performance

(countryName STRING, countryCode STRING, indicatorName STRING, indicatorCode STRING, indicatorValue FLOAT)
PARTITIONED BY (year INTEGER)
ROW FORMAT SERDE 'org.apache.hadoop.hive.serde2.OpenCSVSerde'
LOCATION 'hdfs:///user/ziyang/hive/wdi/wdi_opencsv_text_partitions'

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Performance Analysis

After partitioned by year (which results in 57 partitions 1960 - 2016), the query computation time is massively reduced to 3 seconds, this is because this time the execution engine would only need to scan through the partitioned sub-table with `year=2015`. Therefore, even though creating a new partitioned table may take some time, but if we always want to query against the partitioned column, partitioning can save a large amount of time given its substantial improvement of efficiency.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Columnar File Optimization

In Hive, depending on the binary file format, Hive can support both row-oriented and column-oriented storage format. Traditional RDBMS uses column-oriented format which stores the table columns into rows, and facilitates high performance for `SELECT` clauses as the system only need to read the specified columns instead of every entire row. Now, we will examine how columnar file can improve query efficiency in Hive.

- Block 1: create a table `wdi_csv_parquet` that store the data as a Parquet file
- Block 2: load the data from `wdi_opencsv_text` to the newly created table
- Block 3: compare, using command line tools, the file sizes of the 2 tables
- Block 4 & 5: run the query that output the total number of rows
- Block 6: execute the 2015 Canada GDP Growth query against the Parquet table
- Block 7: performance analysis of the 2 queries

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Performance Analysis

From the result of running the above queries and comparing file size, we observed the following 3 changes:

1. File stored in column-oriented format takes significantly less disk space (137.2MB) than the normal text file (2.3GB)
2. The query to count total number of rows is much faster with column-oriented file (11 seconds) than with the normal text file (50 seconds)
3. The query to output row fields with a `WHERE` clause is much faster with column-oriented file (8 seconds) than with the normal text file (45 seconds)

We have seen that using a column-oriented storage format does optimize both disk usage and query efficiency.

%md
# Highest GDP Growth

Now, we want to query the highest GDP growth and the corresponding year for all countries using both HiveQL and Spark SQL and compare their performance.

- Block 1: execute the query using Tez execution engine
- Block 2: execute the query using Spark execution engine
- Block 3: performance analysis for both engines

msg.data:
Highest GDP Growth

Now, we want to query the highest GDP growth and the corresponding year for all countries using both HiveQL and Spark SQL and compare their performance.

  • Block 1: execute the query using Tez execution engine
  • Block 2: execute the query using Spark execution engine
  • Block 3: performance analysis for both engines

paragraphs.text:
SELECT T1.indicatorValue AS gdp_growth_rate, T1.year, T1.countryName
FROM wdi_csv_parquet T1 INNER JOIN (
    SELECT max(indicatorValue) AS indicatorValue, countryName 
    FROM wdi_csv_parquet
    WHERE indicatorCode='NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG'
    GROUP BY countryName) T2
    ON T1.indicatorValue=T2.indicatorValue AND T1.countryName=T2.countryName
WHERE indicatorCode='NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG'
ORDER BY gdp_growth_rate DESC

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql
SELECT T1.indicatorValue AS gdp_growth_rate, T1.year, T1.countryName
FROM wdi_csv_parquet T1 INNER JOIN (
    SELECT max(indicatorValue) AS indicatorValue, countryName 
    FROM wdi_csv_parquet
    WHERE indicatorCode='NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG'
    GROUP BY countryName) T2
    ON T1.indicatorValue=T2.indicatorValue AND T1.countryName=T2.countryName
WHERE indicatorCode='NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG'
ORDER BY gdp_growth_rate DESC

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Performance Analysis

From the above results, we can see that the Hive Spark SQL execution engine performs much faster (6 seconds) than the default Tez execution engine (17 seconds), and this is because that the Spark engine speeds up execution by storing intermediate query result in RAM rather than local disk space. Therefore, when working with Hive, we would usually prefer using Spark.

msg.data:
Performance Analysis

From the above results, we can see that the Hive Spark SQL execution engine performs much faster (6 seconds) than the default Tez execution engine (17 seconds), and this is because that the Spark engine speeds up execution by storing intermediate query result in RAM rather than local disk space. Therefore, when working with Hive, we would usually prefer using Spark.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Sort GDP by Country and Year

Next, we will write a query to return the GDP growth for all country that sorts by `countryName` and `year`. This time, we will use Spark SQL as the execution engine along with the column-oriented Parquet file, so the query should be very fast!

msg.data:
Sort GDP by Country and Year

Next, we will write a query to return the GDP growth for all country that sorts by countryName and year. This time, we will use Spark SQL as the execution engine along with the column-oriented Parquet file, so the query should be very fast!

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql
SELECT countryName, year, indicatorCode, indicatorValue AS gdp_growth_rate
FROM wdi_csv_parquet
WHERE indicatorCode='NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG'
SORT BY countryName, year
LIMIT 100
